issue.title: LUA Skript Installer doesn't appear
issue.body:
### Describe the bug

When darktable 4.4.1 is started it should display the lua scripts installer module if the lua scripts are not installed, but it does not.

### Steps to reproduce

1. Start darktable 4.4.1
2. No lua scripts installer module appears in the lower left panel

### Expected behavior

lua scripts installer should be present

### Logfile | Screenshot | Screencast

_No response_

### Commit

_No response_

### Where did you install darktable from?

darktable.org

### darktable version

4.4.1

### What OS are you using?

Mac

### What is the version of your OS?

Ventura

### Describe your system?

16 GB Ram i7

### Are you using OpenCL GPU in darktable?

I dont know

### If yes, what is the GPU card and driver?

Intel Iris Plus Graphics 655 1536 MB

### Please provide additional context if applicable. You can attach files too, but might need to rename to .txt or .zip

reproducable

comment.body: Update: switched theme to "darktable" and restarted (I like more visible font) and script manager option disappeared again. Switched back to elegant gray (default) and restarted and it reappeared. Replicated twice.

issue.title: smoothly switch crop on/off

labels.name: bugfix
labels.description: pull request fixing a bug

labels.name: feature: enhancement
labels.description: current features to improve

labels.name: priority: medium
labels.description: core features are degraded in a way that is still mostly usable, software stutters

labels.name: difficulty: hard
labels.description: big changes across different parts of the code base

labels.name: scope: UI
labels.description: user interface and interactions

labels.name: scope: codebase
labels.description: making darktable source code easier to manage

issue.body:
Another follow up to #15084 and #15364. Fixes #15416.
Edit: This is a WIP; don't expect exporting to work (thumbnail generation is thus also broken). Or slideshow. Snapshots and duplicates that have different crop/zoom/position/rotation than the on-screen image will also look weird.

The visible effect of this PR is twofold:
- when the crop of the image in darkroom is switched on or off, for example because the crop module itself or the retouch or liquify modules are (de)focused, the previously visible high resolution image is repositioned and rescaled to the exact new spot where it will end up, while the full image is being recalculated. When "zooming in" (the crop module loses focus; the crop is switched on) this means you should immediately see the correct image, but after the recalculation finishes it will be a little sharper. When "zooming out" (the crop/retouch/liquifty module is focused; the crop is temporarily switched off) this means that the "center" of the image will likely be sharper for a little while than the area around it, which may first be black and then pixilated while a scaled up version of the left-top corner preview is shown until the full recalculation finishes.
In the most extreme case (the crop margins are zero) this should avoid the problem @TurboGit reported here #15286 (no flickering), but it should help in a lot more cases. It also replaces the hacky solution I implemented here #15222.
- when we are currently zoomed in to a cropped image, focusing a module that temporarily switches off cropping (like crop itself but also retouch and liquify) would cause the shown image to move to a completely different area. This is no longer the case, although the image may still be slightly repositioned to move it to center.



This PR was a hellish journey again. To help understand what was needed to be changed and possibly predict/understand some side effects, I'll give a bit of background, also serving maybe as some kind of "documentation" when further changes are considered. Such documentation is completely lacking at the moment as far as I can tell and otherwise probably would not really reflect the actual current implementation and behavior anyway, so might have been worse than the nothing we have.

In the darkroom we have a multitude of coordinate systems to describe a spot in the image:
1. relative position in terms of the "complete" image (the one shown in miniature in the top-left navigator window. This goes from horizontal 0-100% (left-right) and vertical 0-100% (top-bottom).
2. same, but in pixels 0-720 horizontal 0-350 vertical (or a portion of this based on aspect ratio).
3. actually, the buffer defined in 2. is only partially used if `preview_downsampling` is set to 1/2, 1/3 or 1/4.
4. pixel position within the full calculated image based on applied crops/framing/rotation etc. This could be, say 0-3k horizontal and 0-2k vertical for a 24mpixel image that is cropped 50% in both directions.
5. position within the central area of the darkroom. On an FHD monitor, full screen and with all panels hidden, this would be 0-1920 and 0-1080. This still includes a narrow border around the image (set in prefs) and a big white+black border if color calibration mode is switched on.
6. relative position within the currently shown (zoomed) image in the central area of the darkroom (0-100% both).
7. same, but in pixels. This is 5 minus the borders.
8. - 10. same as 5-7 but for the second preview window.
11. corresponding position of any of the previous points in terms of the original raw file. In 0-100%. The 50% crop in 4. could for example be 50-100% and 25-75%, if the right half of the image positioned centrally vertically was used.
12. same in pixels; 3k-6k and 1k-3k for the example above.

These coordinate system are used while redrawing the screen and processing mouse moves and clicks and when dealing with visual elements like mask shapes, color picker areas and crop or perspective handles etc etc. Variables names don't indicate what coordinate system an "x" or "y" lives in (or at least I haven't discovered the consistency and I haven't myself improved the situation I'm sure). In _most_ places, we somehow reference back to a position within the "full" (i.e. current crop) image, but scaled down, that is shown in the navigator window (2. i.e. not necessarily corrected for downsampling; this correction needed to be applied every time before anything was done with it, so _all_ the individual modules etc were dealing with downsampling over and over again).

We have "current positions" for the center screen and the second preview window and the last calculated zoomed in "preview" for each of these, which may have been from a time that a crop was or wasn't active that currently isn't or is.

Basically, this PR stores the current position and the positions of the calculated previews in coordinate system 12 (the context of the RAW file, which is immutable) and then when drawing positions them on the center and second preview areas based on current crop and zoom levels and locations.

That sounds trivial and to avoid introducing a lot of new bugs one obviously tries to be minimally invasive when making changes and reconnecting to existing code. But similar past changes introduced back and forth conversions everywhere to the extend that it really impossible to comprehend what is going on. So I had to try to create some order out of chaos. Again, starting with not making too big changes so that the impact could more easily be tested, but eventually in frustration, because it was impossible to get everything to line up, ending up completely ripping out _all_ the references to downsampling and instead at startup reducing the dimensions of the "preview" (navigator) miniature. This miraculously got rid of a lot of issues with no problems introduced as far as I could tell (please _do_ tell if you find any). Similarly, after calculating a preview image (full res) for the zoomed+cropped, the resoluting pixmap would be stored in a variable (with associated dimension variables) called "backbuf". For some reason, at some point a duplicate of these variables called "output_backbuf" was created and extensively used. Because the dimensions of the pixmap are somewhat related (after scaling) to the common "standard" of the full "preview" pixmap, the code ended up with references to `output_backbuf_width/height` everywhere.

The output buffers are only available once the calculations are finished (which doesn't happen at the same time for the preview/full/preview2 pipes) so their sizes and zoom levels get out of sync with the current zoom and crop. This PR tries to base the shown image on the actual current zoom and crop levels, but unfortunately can't convert RAW dimensions back and forth to the current zoomed-and-cropped screen image until a pipe has been refreshed based on the current history (which gets partly flushed whenever a module (un)focus happens) and might not get recreated soon if a long calculation is already underway. And many modules don't draw their visual elements anyway until the _preview_ is available...

So, yeah, this PR is not perfect. Further improvements will need work done on cache and possibly pipe handling. I may start an issue to discuss my thoughts there first, because I definitely want to tap into the knowledge of @TurboGit and @jenshannoschwalm  and possibly others who currently know more about those areas than I do, because the changes required would be somewhat extensive and gradual steps are not likely to be productive.

Things you will notice when testing this PR:
- snapshots and duplicates work, but if they are activated while the currently visible image has a wildly different size, crop or  orientation, they will be shown in an odd location.
- slideshow is not connected up to the new approach at all yet; it doesn't work.
- When rotating the image, the scaled preview and repositioned last calculated full view will be temporarily combined in an odd juxtaposition. It is probably necessary to determine and store the rotation (and flip) of a calculated image relative to the original raw when a pipe calculation finishes and the result is stored in the backbuf. We can then ask cairo to rotate+flip as an approximation or just temporarily hide the last full res image. Previously this wasn't an issue because we just continued showing the old image in the same location while the recalc was ongoing; we were not attempting to relocate/zoom to a predicted new location.

Please give this PR a go and tell me your thoughts; any specific cases that you feel might need special handling and are not getting it here. Any showstoppers that might make it practically infeasible to get this approach working correctly ever. Or just any questions the above has raised for you or that could be explained (much) better.

EDIT: when testing changes like these, that are intended to make working with sets of heavy modules on slower machines (laptops lacking GPUs for example) bearable and on faster machines more fluid, it makes sense to test with some serious modules (d&s, blurs, liquify) enabled and possibly even switch off OpenCL.

EDIT 2: This also fixes some memory leaks in snapshots and duplicates; pixmap bufs were allocated and filled and then cairo surfaces based on them. The surfaces were correctly destroyed afterwards, but since they didn't take ownership of the pixmaps, those still need to be `dt_free_align`ed as well.

comment.body:
On the other hand, (permanently) removing a shortcut is very easy these days and if the user already had alt+b set to something else, that will continue to take precedence. "Taking a shortcut" is not really _that_ big a deal.

So the argument to keep the shortcut is that in master it is very easy to toggle 2nd window color assessment by shortcut and this convenience would be lost. It's easier to write in release notes "shortcut is now alt+b" rather than "go figure out how to set up shortcuts in preferences and then open a GitHub account just to file a complaint that in this particular instance that's not as easy as you would like it to be because visual mapping doesn't work out of the box".

issue.title: macOS System Shortcuts Do Not Work

labels.name: scope: macos support
labels.description: macos related issues and PR

issue.body:
### Describe the bug

On macOS, ⌘ A, ⌘ C, ⌘ X, and ⌘ V are system-wide shortcuts for select-all, copy, cut, and paste, respectively. In darktable, they do not work; you must use Ctrl-A, Ctrl-C, Ctrl-X, and Ctrl-V instead.

### Steps to reproduce

1. Run darktable on macOS.
2. Focus a text box, like the filter text box in lighttable.
3. Type some letters, like `asdf`.
4. Press ⌘ A ⌘ X.

Nothing happens.

### Expected behavior

All the text is selected and then deleted, and populates the clipboard.

### Logfile | Screenshot | Screencast

_No response_

### Commit

_No response_

### Where did you install darktable from?

darktable.org

### darktable version

4.4.2

### What OS are you using?

Linux

### What is the version of your OS?

macOS Sonoma 14.0

### Describe your system?

MacBook Pro 13-inch, M1, 2020

### Are you using OpenCL GPU in darktable?

I dont know

### If yes, what is the GPU card and driver?

_No response_

### Please provide additional context if applicable. You can attach files too, but might need to rename to .txt or .zip

_No response_

comment.body:
FWIW, I think that auto-closing issues (and the related warnings from the bot) is a bad policy. A lot of successful FOSS projects have outstanding issues that have been open for years, if not decades. This does not mean that they are irrelevant, and won't be fixed at some point. Even if the OP cannot fix them, someone may come along in due course, or find a host of related issues when doing a refactoring, etc.

I understand that having a lot of open issues can be disheartening as a maintainer, but it is effectively harmless when handled appropriately. Labeling, periodic culling and re-triage of issues is a much better policy. See eg this [recent discussion at Kubernetes](https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/issues/103151) and their [subsequent solution](https://github.com/kubernetes/test-infra/pull/28266).

issue.title: Rework temperature and channelmixerrgb

labels.name: scope: color management
labels.description: ensuring consistency of colour adaptation through display/output profiles

labels.name: scope: codebase
labels.description: making darktable source code easier to manage

issue.body:
This implements a
`chroma` struct in dev (like a proxy) holding all required and available white balance data for the current image (D65, as_shot and currently used) allowing runtime

a) check - are we using D65?
b) access of modules to the other coeffs for improved results c) easier and safe checks for chroma correction related trouble messages

@TurboGit for you as this might be easier to review.
It's a stripped down version of #15461, this should not change anything in current master behaviour except safer message generation and keeping data in the dev chroma struct. The other pr could be rebased on this after possibly getting merged.

Fixes #14518

comment.body: Thanks @jenshannoschwalm for your work and the fix.

review.body: Better to me and after your explanation in original PR I'm ok with the order in the new wording.

pull_request.title: Fix the text of one of the choices in initial dialog for "copy & import"
pull_request.body: This is an alternative to the fix proposed in #15463. In it, we do not change the logic of dialog behavior to match the text on the button, but on the contrary, we change the text to match the behavior.

issue.title: Some minor refresh issue on color calibration module

labels.name: scope: UI
labels.description: user interface and interactions

labels.name: bug: pending
labels.description: someone needs to start working on that

issue.body:
### Describe the bug

Since #14498 is fixed, if I change a setting on white balance then revert back to default setting, color calibration module shows "error, on white balance module" with red warning. This should disappear when put back related white balance default and at least on opening module. This is no more the case. But error message disappear when quitting darkroom and go back to the image.

I think some refresh issue is missing after change regarding fix of #14498. @ralfbrown?

### Steps to reproduce

With an image with scene-referred workflow, so white balance on bulb icon (6502K value):
1) click on pencil icon on white balance module
2) click on bulb icon to revert to default settings
3) see error message appear on color calibration module.

Quit darkroom and go back to the image: the error message had disappear.

### Expected behavior

error message disappear as soon as white balance setting is again ok for color calibration module

### Logfile | Screenshot | Screencast

_No response_

### Commit

_No response_

### Where did you install darktable from?

darktable.org

### darktable version

last master at the time of writing that issue

### What OS are you using?

Linux

### What is the version of your OS?

Debian Sid

### Describe your system?

_No response_

### Are you using OpenCL GPU in darktable?

None

### If yes, what is the GPU card and driver?

_No response_

### Please provide additional context if applicable. You can attach files too, but might need to rename to .txt or .zip

_No response_

commits.message:
Rework temperature and channelmixerrgb

This implements a
`chroma` struct in dev (like a proxy) holding all required and available white balance data for
the current image (D65, as_shot and currently used) allowing runtime

a) check - are we using D65?
b) access of modules to the other coeffs for improved results
c) easier and safe checks for chroma correction related trouble messages

pull_request.title: Rework temperature and channelmixerrgb
pull_request.body:
This implements a
`chroma` struct in dev (like a proxy) holding all required and available white balance data for the current image (D65, as_shot and currently used) allowing runtime

a) check - are we using D65?
b) access of modules to the other coeffs for improved results c) easier and safe checks for chroma correction related trouble messages

@TurboGit for you as this might be easier to review.
It's a stripped down version of #15461, this should not change anything in current master behaviour except safer message generation and keeping data in the dev chroma struct. The other pr could be rebased on this after possibly getting merged.

Fixes #14518

issue.body:
### Describe the bug

When you're using Chinese IME (Zhuyin) and want to adjust the value of module with the numeric keypad in darktable 4.4.2. darktable will crash immediately.
This happened on Win10 and Win11, but it won't happen on Linux with Chewing.
I know that there are few people using Chinese IME (Zhuyin) with darktable, and it's not a big problem for me. So if you're busy on other more important issues,  just ignore this.

### Steps to reproduce

Change to Chinese IME (Zhuyin) and adjust any  modules with numeric keypad.

### Expected behavior

_No response_

_No response_

_No response_

darktable.org

darktable 4.4.2

Windows

Yes

Nv4060ti 940m and 1650

_No response_

Many thanks for reporting (and, in advance, for testing).

issue.title: Second window do not change show crop region when using Retouch or Liquify

labels.name: priority: medium
labels.description: core features are degraded in a way that is still mostly usable, software stutters

labels.name: feature: redesign
labels.description: current features to rewrite

labels.name: scope: image processing
labels.description: correcting pixels

issue.body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**

If an image has been cropped and we open Retouch or Liquify the whole image is displayed and the crop region drawn as an overlay. This has been done to make it possible to use some cropped region as source for Retouch for example. All fine.

The same behavior is done for the second window. I don't think this is necessary (we don't work on this view)  nor good. The second window should be kept as the view of the final image. 

**Describe the solution you'd like**

Never uncrop the second window.

issue.title: Panasonic DC-ZS200D is in rawspeed cameras.xml but raw format not supported
issue.body:
### Describe the bug

Darktable cannot open a raw file taken on my DC-ZS200D yet this is a supported camera
UPDATE: Attempted SELF-FIX 

Appended <Alias>DC-ZS200D</Alias> to <Camera make="Panasonic" model="DC-TZ202" mode="3:2">in cameras.xml
and it works fine now.
Section of XML Edited:
```
<Camera make="Panasonic" model="DC-TZ202" mode="3:2">
		<ID make="Panasonic" model="DC-TZ202">Panasonic DC-ZS200</ID>
		<Crop x="0" y="0" width="0" height="0"/>
		<Sensor black="142" white="4095"/>
		<Aliases>
			<Alias>DC-TZ200</Alias>
			<Alias>DC-ZS200</Alias>
			<!--LINE ADDED-->
			<Alias>DC-ZS200D</Alias>
		</Aliases>

``` 
Note that the DC-ZS200D is a 3:2 sensor camera and the default mode appears to be "3:2"
Seems to work for raw files
### Steps to reproduce

1. Open folder in Darktable and import raw files from folder using "add to library"
2. Thumbnails show up but cannot be made fullscreen by clicking on them
3. I checked cameras.xml and do have the latest version

### Expected behavior

open the raw file successfully

### Logfile | Screenshot | Screencast
Logfile:
[darktable-log.txt](https://github.com/darktable-org/darktable/files/13183156/darktable-log.txt)
Note:

issue.title: smoothly switch crop on/off

labels.name: bugfix
labels.description: pull request fixing a bug

labels.name: feature: enhancement
labels.description: current features to improve

labels.name: priority: medium
labels.description: core features are degraded in a way that is still mostly usable, software stutters

labels.name: difficulty: hard
labels.description: big changes across different parts of the code base

labels.name: scope: UI
labels.description: user interface and interactions

labels.name: scope: codebase
labels.description: making darktable source code easier to manage

issue.body:
Another follow up to #15084 and #15364. Fixes #15416.
Edit: This is a WIP; don't expect exporting to work (thumbnail generation is thus also broken). Or slideshow. Snapshots and duplicates that have different crop/zoom/position/rotation than the on-screen image will also look weird.

The visible effect of this PR is twofold:
- when the crop of the image in darkroom is switched on or off, for example because the crop module itself or the retouch or liquify modules are (de)focused, the previously visible high resolution image is repositioned and rescaled to the exact new spot where it will end up, while the full image is being recalculated. When "zooming in" (the crop module loses focus; the crop is switched on) this means you should immediately see the correct image, but after the recalculation finishes it will be a little sharper. When "zooming out" (the crop/retouch/liquifty module is focused; the crop is temporarily switched off) this means that the "center" of the image will likely be sharper for a little while than the area around it, which may first be black and then pixilated while a scaled up version of the left-top corner preview is shown until the full recalculation finishes.
In the most extreme case (the crop margins are zero) this should avoid the problem @TurboGit reported here #15286 (no flickering), but it should help in a lot more cases. It also replaces the hacky solution I implemented here #15222.
- when we are currently zoomed in to a cropped image, focusing a module that temporarily switches off cropping (like crop itself but also retouch and liquify) would cause the shown image to move to a completely different area. This is no longer the case, although the image may still be slightly repositioned to move it to center.



This PR was a hellish journey again. To help understand what was needed to be changed and possibly predict/understand some side effects, I'll give a bit of background, also serving maybe as some kind of "documentation" when further changes are considered. Such documentation is completely lacking at the moment as far as I can tell and otherwise probably would not really reflect the actual current implementation and behavior anyway, so might have been worse than the nothing we have.

In the darkroom we have a multitude of coordinate systems to describe a spot in the image:
1. relative position in terms of the "complete" image (the one shown in miniature in the top-left navigator window. This goes from horizontal 0-100% (left-right) and vertical 0-100% (top-bottom).
2. same, but in pixels 0-720 horizontal 0-350 vertical (or a portion of this based on aspect ratio).
3. actually, the buffer defined in 2. is only partially used if `preview_downsampling` is set to 1/2, 1/3 or 1/4.
4. pixel position within the full calculated image based on applied crops/framing/rotation etc. This could be, say 0-3k horizontal and 0-2k vertical for a 24mpixel image that is cropped 50% in both directions.
5. position within the central area of the darkroom. On an FHD monitor, full screen and with all panels hidden, this would be 0-1920 and 0-1080. This still includes a narrow border around the image (set in prefs) and a big white+black border if color calibration mode is switched on.
6. relative position within the currently shown (zoomed) image in the central area of the darkroom (0-100% both).
7. same, but in pixels. This is 5 minus the borders.
8. - 10. same as 5-7 but for the second preview window.
11. corresponding position of any of the previous points in terms of the original raw file. In 0-100%. The 50% crop in 4. could for example be 50-100% and 25-75%, if the right half of the image positioned centrally vertically was used.
12. same in pixels; 3k-6k and 1k-3k for the example above.

These coordinate system are used while redrawing the screen and processing mouse moves and clicks and when dealing with visual elements like mask shapes, color picker areas and crop or perspective handles etc etc. Variables names don't indicate what coordinate system an "x" or "y" lives in (or at least I haven't discovered the consistency and I haven't myself improved the situation I'm sure). In _most_ places, we somehow reference back to a position within the "full" (i.e. current crop) image, but scaled down, that is shown in the navigator window (2. i.e. not necessarily corrected for downsampling; this correction needed to be applied every time before anything was done with it, so _all_ the individual modules etc were dealing with downsampling over and over again).

We have "current positions" for the center screen and the second preview window and the last calculated zoomed in "preview" for each of these, which may have been from a time that a crop was or wasn't active that currently isn't or is.

Basically, this PR stores the current position and the positions of the calculated previews in coordinate system 12 (the context of the RAW file, which is immutable) and then when drawing positions them on the center and second preview areas based on current crop and zoom levels and locations.

That sounds trivial and to avoid introducing a lot of new bugs one obviously tries to be minimally invasive when making changes and reconnecting to existing code. But similar past changes introduced back and forth conversions everywhere to the extend that it really impossible to comprehend what is going on. So I had to try to create some order out of chaos. Again, starting with not making too big changes so that the impact could more easily be tested, but eventually in frustration, because it was impossible to get everything to line up, ending up completely ripping out _all_ the references to downsampling and instead at startup reducing the dimensions of the "preview" (navigator) miniature. This miraculously got rid of a lot of issues with no problems introduced as far as I could tell (please _do_ tell if you find any). Similarly, after calculating a preview image (full res) for the zoomed+cropped, the resoluting pixmap would be stored in a variable (with associated dimension variables) called "backbuf". For some reason, at some point a duplicate of these variables called "output_backbuf" was created and extensively used. Because the dimensions of the pixmap are somewhat related (after scaling) to the common "standard" of the full "preview" pixmap, the code ended up with references to `output_backbuf_width/height` everywhere.

The output buffers are only available once the calculations are finished (which doesn't happen at the same time for the preview/full/preview2 pipes) so their sizes and zoom levels get out of sync with the current zoom and crop. This PR tries to base the shown image on the actual current zoom and crop levels, but unfortunately can't convert RAW dimensions back and forth to the current zoomed-and-cropped screen image until a pipe has been refreshed based on the current history (which gets partly flushed whenever a module (un)focus happens) and might not get recreated soon if a long calculation is already underway. And many modules don't draw their visual elements anyway until the _preview_ is available...

So, yeah, this PR is not perfect. Further improvements will need work done on cache and possibly pipe handling. I may start an issue to discuss my thoughts there first, because I definitely want to tap into the knowledge of @TurboGit and @jenshannoschwalm  and possibly others who currently know more about those areas than I do, because the changes required would be somewhat extensive and gradual steps are not likely to be productive.

Things you will notice when testing this PR:
- snapshots and duplicates work, but if they are activated while the currently visible image has a wildly different size, crop or  orientation, they will be shown in an odd location.
- slideshow is not connected up to the new approach at all yet; it doesn't work.
- When rotating the image, the scaled preview and repositioned last calculated full view will be temporarily combined in an odd juxtaposition. It is probably necessary to determine and store the rotation (and flip) of a calculated image relative to the original raw when a pipe calculation finishes and the result is stored in the backbuf. We can then ask cairo to rotate+flip as an approximation or just temporarily hide the last full res image. Previously this wasn't an issue because we just continued showing the old image in the same location while the recalc was ongoing; we were not attempting to relocate/zoom to a predicted new location.

Please give this PR a go and tell me your thoughts; any specific cases that you feel might need special handling and are not getting it here. Any showstoppers that might make it practically infeasible to get this approach working correctly ever. Or just any questions the above has raised for you or that could be explained (much) better.

EDIT: when testing changes like these, that are intended to make working with sets of heavy modules on slower machines (laptops lacking GPUs for example) bearable and on faster machines more fluid, it makes sense to test with some serious modules (d&s, blurs, liquify) enabled and possibly even switch off OpenCL.

EDIT 2: This also fixes some memory leaks in snapshots and duplicates; pixmap bufs were allocated and filled and then cairo surfaces based on them. The surfaces were correctly destroyed afterwards, but since they didn't take ownership of the pixmaps, those still need to be `dt_free_align`ed as well.

comment.body:
> OK with that or would you prefer it removed? 

I'll prefer removing the shortcut `Alt+b` because the second window is not used a lot and so don't think it is a good idea to take a shortcut by default.

> But on the other hand, I imagine this is maybe less frequently used

Exactly my thinking too.

Apart from that it works fine on my side now. So ready to be merged as soon as the shortcut is removed.

issue.title: Second window do not change show crop region when using Retouch or Liquify

labels.name: priority: medium
labels.description: core features are degraded in a way that is still mostly usable, software stutters

labels.name: feature: redesign
labels.description: current features to rewrite

labels.name: scope: image processing
labels.description: correcting pixels

issue.body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**

If an image has been cropped and we open Retouch or Liquify the whole image is displayed and the crop region drawn as an overlay. This has been done to make it possible to use some cropped region as source for Retouch for example. All fine.

The same behavior is done for the second window. I don't think this is necessary (we don't work on this view)  nor good. The second window should be kept as the view of the final image. 

**Describe the solution you'd like**

Never uncrop the second window.

labels.name: scope: image processing
labels.description: correcting pixels

issue.body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**

If an image has been cropped and we open Retouch or Liquify the whole image is displayed and the crop region drawn as an overlay. This has been done to make it possible to use some cropped region as source for Retouch for example. All fine.

The same behavior is done for the second window. I don't think this is necessary (we don't work on this view)  nor good. The second window should be kept as the view of the final image. 

**Describe the solution you'd like**

Never uncrop the second window.

issue.title: fix crash when entering Chinese in bauhaus popup

labels.name: bugfix
labels.description: pull request fixing a bug

labels.name: scope: translation / strings
labels.description: make darktable international

labels.name: priority: high
labels.description: core features are broken and not usable at all, software crashes

labels.name: difficulty: trivial
labels.description: some changes in a couple of functions

labels.name: scope: windows support
labels.description: windows related issues and PR

issue.body:
fixes #15485

You still can't type Chinese in a combobox popup, but shouldn't crash (just ignores).

At least, this is with my limited testing and without much understanding of how Chinese IMEs work. if you can still make it crash, please provide clear instructions how I can reproduce on Win11 with a US keyboard layout.

Many thanks for reporting (and, in advance, for testing).

comment.body:
I would love to help on testing. But I have no skills of building installation packages (tried, but failure).

This is the guide of how to add input language in Windows, if you needed.
https://support.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/manage-the-input-and-display-language-settings-in-windows-12a10cb4-8626-9b77-0ccb-5013e0c7c7a2#WindowsVersion=Windows_11

If you added Chinese Traditional (Taiwan) keyboard, input **"H K 4 enter"**. That's how to type "測" (means testing) in Chinese Traditional (Taiwan) 注音 input layout. It might show other words in the same pronounce, but it won't cause any effects of the testing result.

Or, if someone builds the package contains this PR, I could test it.

release.name: Darktable nightly build 20231027
release.body:
This is a nightly build of Darktable.

You can use this if you want to try new features without waiting for releases.
From time to time, in development builds, old difficult-to-reproduce bugs are
fixed, but it is also true that in the development process with the introduction
of new complex code, the stability of the program may suffer compared to
official releases, so **use it with caution**!

Also, new versions can make changes to the database schema, so it's best to run
them with a separate library.

The `*.AppImage.zsync` file is not intended to be downloaded and used locally.
Just ignore it. This file contains technical information required by AppImage
auto-updaters such as [AppImageUpdate](https://appimage.github.io/AppImageUpdate/).

__Please help us improve Darktable by reporting any issues you encounter!__ :wink:
release.short_description_html:
This is a nightly build of Darktable.

You can use this if you want to try new features without waiting for releases.
From time to time, in development builds, old difficult-to-reproduce bugs are
fi…

issue.title: Flash EXIF tag missing in the Image Information Panel

labels.name: feature: enhancement
labels.description: current features to improve

issue.body:
Hi,
the image information gives a great list of info on each image especially from EXIF tags. And this is great.
Nevertheless, one of them is not imported or shown : the Flash tag.
The Flash tag brings highly relevant info in many cases.
This is not specifically an issue nor a bug, but a lack from my point of view.
Could you please show it in the list in a future release?
Many thanks for your support and congratulations to all darktable contributors.

Note : using 4.0.1 rel on Windows.
Best regards

comment.body: This issue has been marked as stale due to inactivity for the last 60 days. It will be automatically closed in 300 days if no update occurs. Please check if the master branch has fixed it and report again or close the issue.
